conclusion: Determine whether light b will undergo total internal reflection before light a when both are incident at the same angle from glass to air, and this angle is gradually increased.
Equilateral triangular glass prism with two monochromatic light rays (a and b) entering the glass from air, perpendicular to the hypotenuse.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a denser medium to a less dense medium at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.
Critical angle depends on the refractive indices according to θc = sin⁻¹(n₂/n₁).
Refractive index of a medium for a given color of light depends on the wavelength, known as dispersion.
Angles i₁ and i₂ are angles of incidence from inside the glass to the air; angles r₁ and r₂ are corresponding angles of refraction.
For TIR to occur, the angle of incidence must exceed the critical angle, which depends on the refractive index and wavelength of light.
Light with shorter wavelengths generally has a higher refractive index than light with longer wavelengths.
Critical angle formula for monochromatic light is θc = sin⁻¹(1/n), where n is the refractive index of glass for that wavelength.
If light b has a higher refractive index than light a, then the critical angle for light b will be smaller than for light a.
Light b will reach its critical angle first as the angle of incidence is gradually increased.
Light b will undergo total internal reflection before light a if b has a shorter wavelength (higher refractive index) than a.
Based on conventional physics understanding of dispersion, if b represents a shorter wavelength than a, then the statement is correct.
